DataElement.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation Nucleated Blood Cell Infusion Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value to represent the total number of nucleated cells reinfused during a peripheral blood stem cell transplantation.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hematopoietic Stem Cell Infusion Nucleated Red Blood Cell Laboratory Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)_._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstreamA specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an_Red blood cells that are at the last stage of development, still containing a nucleus, that are found in the bone marrow and occasionally in the peripheral blood._A medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood, urine, or other substance from the body. Tests can help determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, check to see if treatment is working, or monitor the disease over time.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Hematopoietic Stem Cell Infusion Procedure Nucleated Red Blood Cell
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.):A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion.:Red blood cells that are at the last stage of development, still containing a nucleus, that are found in the bone marrow and occasionally in the peripheral blood.

Concepts.definition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)
Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
Red blood cells that are at the last stage of development, still containing a nucleus, that are found in the bone marrow and occasionally in the peripheral blood.

Property.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation Nucleated Blood Cell Infusion Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Similar to bone marrow transplantation, peripheral stem cell transplantation is a method of replacing the blood-forming cells lost due to high-dose chemotherapy, and possibly radiation therapy, used to destroy leukemia cells. Certain immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells.  Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin)._The cellular material of blood consisting of white blood cells and nucleated red blood cells.A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation Nucleated Blood Cell Infusion Procedure Value
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Similar to bone marrow transplantation, peripheral stem cell transplantation is a method of replacing the blood-forming cells lost due to high-dose chemotherapy, and possibly radiation therapy, used to destroy leukemia cells. Certain immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells.  Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).:The cellular material of blood consisting of white blood cells and nucleated red blood cells.:A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: A method of hematopoietic reconstitution utilizing stem cells harvested from the circulating blood of a patient or donor. Peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) is used for the treatment of certain blood disorders, following partial or complete bone marrow ablation, or following high dose chemotherapy or radiation treatment for cancer. Immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells. Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).
The cellular material of blood consisting of white blood cells and nucleated red blood cells.
Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated for Duke University clinical trial
